item.title: Taiwan’s strongest earthquake in 25 years kills at least 9
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Jett and Janis Mackey Frayer and Dawn Liu and Rae Wang and Emma Li and Arata Yamamoto and Larissa Gao and Phil Helsel
item.description: A 7.4-magnitude earthquake struck Wednesday off the coast of Taiwan, killing at least four people in the island’s most powerful tremor in at least 25 years.

media:content.media:text: A damaged building in Hualien City, Taiwan, after an earthquake
media:content.media:description: A damaged building in Hualien City, Taiwan, after an earthquake on April 3, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Worst Taiwan Quake in 25 Years Levels Buildings
media:content.media:description: A collapsed road in New Taipei City following the earthquake.

media:content.media:text: Taiwan Earthquake Damage
media:content.media:description: A local resident inspects damage to a brick wall inside a home in Taipei.

item.title: Iran vows retaliation on Israel after commanders’ deaths, raising fears of war spiraling
item.dc:creator: Alexander Smith and Reuters
item.description: Monday’s airstrike on Damascus is reverberating across the Middle East, raising fears that the war between Israel and Hamas could flare into a wider conflict.

media:content.media:text: Syrian state media said Israeli strikes hit an Iranian consular annex in the capital on April 1, while a war monitor reported eight people were killed and Iranian state media said a senior commander of the powerful Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps was among the dead, amid rising regional tensions due to the Gaza war.
media:content.media:description: Emergency personnel extinguish a fire after a building annexed to the Iranian embassy in Syria's capital Damascus was damaged by an Israeli strike, on April 1, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Iranian General Mohammad Reza Zahedi
media:content.media:description: Iranian Brig. Gen. Mohammad Reza Zahedi.

media:content.media:text: Iran warned arch foe Israel on April 2 that it will punish an air strike that killed seven Revolutionary Guards, two of them generals, at its consular annex in Damascus.
media:content.media:description: Rescue workers search the rubble of a building next to the Iranian Embassy a day after an airstrike in Damascus, Syria, on Tuesday.

item.title: DHS attempts to stop a steady stream of guns from America to Haiti
item.dc:creator: Guad Venegas and Fredlyn Pierre Louis
item.description: The Department of Homeland Security is trying to stop the illegal flow of high-powered guns from the U.S. to Haiti, as the Caribbean nation reels from violence and instability wrought by armed groups and gangs.

media:content.media:text: A G-9 federation gang member holds a gun
media:content.media:description: A G-9 federation gang member in the Delmas 3 area in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, on Feb. 22, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Confiscated guns lay on a table
media:content.media:description: Weapons confiscated by HSI Miami are displayed during a press conference to announce a crackdown on the smuggling of firearms to Haiti and other Caribbean nations in 2022.

item.title: Biden 'outraged' by Israeli strike that killed aid workers in Gaza
item.dc:creator: Megan Lebowitz
item.description: The president's statement — his first comments on the deaths of World Central Kitchen humanitarian workers — contained some of his strongest criticism of Israel.

media:content.media:text: President Joe Biden delivers remarks at the White House
media:content.media:description: President Joe Biden in the Roosevelt Room of the White House on March 26.

item.title: Israeli strike hits aid convoy, killing 7 World Central Kitchen workers in Gaza
item.dc:creator: Yuliya Talmazan and Associated Press
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Tuesday his country’s forces had “unintentionally hit innocent people” in the Gaza Strip in the past day, after an airstrike killed seven aid workers with the disaster relief charity World Central Kitchen.

media:content.media:text: The international food aid charity said on April 2 it was pausing its Gaza aid operations after seven of its staff were killed in a "targeted Israeli strike" as they unloaded desperately needed food aid delivered by sea from Cyprus.
media:content.media:description: People gather around a World Central Kitchen vehicle that was hit by an Israeli strike the previous day in Deir al-Balah in the central Gaza Strip on April 2, 2024.

media:content.media:text: World Central Kitchen Gaza
media:content.media:description: Relatives and friends mourned the deaths as they gathered in Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip on Tuesday.

media:content.media:text: World Central Kitchen Aid Worker Funeral
media:content.media:description: The body of a staff member of the U.S.-based aid group was carried through the streets of Rafah during his funeral.

media:content.media:text: World Central Kitchen vehicles struck in Gaza
media:content.media:description: People gathered Tuesday around one of the cars that was hit by the strike in Deir al-Balah in the central Gaza Strip.

item.title: 'I kept on saying goodbye': Gaza hospital reports rise in stillbirths and infant deaths
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva
item.description: Doctors at a Gaza hospital say a growing number of women have suffered pregnancy losses or complications, and there has been a rise in stillbirths and neonatal deaths.

media:content.media:text: premature babies underweight small baby malnourished
media:content.media:description: Premature babies rest at Emirati Hospital in Rafah, Gaza Strip.

item.title: She secretly educated herself to escape Afghanistan. Now, she's working to help women still there
item.dc:creator: Maya Eaglin
item.description: Sola Mahfouz stopped going to school in 2007 when she was an 11-year-old living in Afghanistan.

media:content.media:text: A portrait of Sola Mahfouz
media:content.media:description: Sola Mahfouz.

media:content.media:credit: Courtesy Sola Mahfouz and Malaina Kapoor
media:content.media:text: Sola Mahfouz and Malaina Kapour laugh while speaking.
media:content.media:description: Sola Mahfouz, left, and Malaina Kapoor.

media:content.media:credit: Courtesy Sola Mahfouz and Malaina Kapour

item.title: Meet the families who've taken children as young as 2 to Everest Base Camp
item.dc:creator: Aria Bendix
item.description: A handful of families have taken children as young as 2 years old to Mount Everest Base Camp in recent years. Three of them describe the experience.

media:content.media:text: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.
media:content.media:description: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

media:content.media:text: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, last year when Arishka was just 6 years old.
media:content.media:description: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, to Everest Base Camp last year at 6 years old.

media:content.media:text: Chris and Cindy Matulis with their kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.
media:content.media:description: Chris and Cindy Matulis with their kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

media:content.media:text: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, last year when Arishka was just 6 years old.
media:content.media:description: Dimple Laddha and Arishka last year.

media:content.media:text: The Matulis kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.
media:content.media:description: The Matulis kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

item.title: Looking for leads, not love: Job seekers in China turn Tinder into a networking tool
item.dc:creator: Larissa Gao and Helen Chen
item.description: Young people in China facing an increasingly tough labor market are turning to an unlikely place for help in their job searches: Tinder.

media:content.media:text: Photo Illustration: A man's Tinder profile reads "Looking for Full-tim employment"
media:content.media:description: Some young people in China see Tinder as a way to find potential job leads.

media:content.media:text: China Youth Unemployment
media:content.media:description: University students at a job fair in Wuhan, China, in March.

item.title: How the Israel-Hamas conflict has spread beyond the Mideast
item.dc:creator: Alexander Smith and JoElla Carman and Jiachuan Wu
item.description: Four months into the war, fighting has spread from Gaza to Pakistan.

item.title: Eight cruise passengers stranded on remote island after missing call time
item.description: Eight passengers, including six Americans and two Australians, were stranded on a remote island off of the coast of Africa after they missed their ship's all aboard call time. All passengers eventually boarded the ship and will be reimbursed for their travel costs, according to the Norwegian Cruise Line.

media:content.media:title: Eight cruise passengers stranded on remote island after missing call time
media:content.media:description: Eight passengers, including six Americans and two Australians, were stranded on a remote island off of the coast of Africa after they missed their ship's all aboard call time. All passengers eventually boarded the ship and will be reimbursed for their travel costs, according to the Norwegian Cruise Line.

item.title: Magnitude 7.4 earthquake rattles the coast of Taiwan
item.description: Several buildings have collapsed in Hualien, Taiwan, after a 7.4 magnitude earthquake struck on the east coast of Taiwan around 8 a.m. local time.

media:content.media:title: Magnitude 7.4 earthquake rattles the coast of Taiwan
media:content.media:description: Several buildings have collapsed in Hualien, Taiwan, after a 7.4 magnitude earthquake struck on the east coast of Taiwan around 8 a.m. local time.

item.title: American cruise passengers faced travel nightmare after being left behind
item.description: The passengers were late for the scheduled departure, so the Norwegian Cruise Lines ship set sail without them from an island in Africa, leading to a days-long journey to catch up with the ship. NBC News' Erin McLaughlin reports.

media:content.media:title: American cruise passengers faced travel nightmare after being left behind
media:content.media:description: The passengers were late for the scheduled departure, so the Norwegian Cruise Lines ship set sail without them from an island in Africa, leading to a days-long journey to catch up with the ship. NBC News' Erin McLaughlin reports.

item.title: Video shows deadly blaze destroying Istanbul nightclub
item.description: At least 29 people were killed in a fire at the Masquerade nightclub while it was closed for renovations in the Besiktas area of Istanbul. Several people, including nightclub managers, have been detained for questioning.

media:content.media:title: Video shows deadly blaze destroying Istanbul nightclub
media:content.media:description: At least 29 people were killed in a fire at the Masquerade nightclub while it was closed for renovations in the Besiktas area of Istanbul. Several people, including nightclub managers, have been detained for questioning.

item.title: Suspects in the stabbing of an Iranian presenter fled U.K. after attack, counterterrorism police say
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: British counterterrorism police investigating the stabbing of a journalist who works for a TV channel critical of the Iranian government said that three suspects had fled the country within hours of the attack.

media:content.media:text: Suspects in the stabbing of an Iranian presenter fled UK after attack, counterterrorism police say
media:content.media:description: Pouria Zeraati in an image released on March 30, 2024.

item.title: Ugandan court rejects bid to nullify anti-gay law that provides for the death penalty in some cases
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Uganda’s constitutional court on Wednesday upheld an anti-gay law that allows the death penalty for “aggravated homosexuality.”

media:content.media:credit: Gallo Images via Getty Images file
media:content.media:text: EFF Picket Against Uganda's Anti-Homosexuality Bill In South Africa
media:content.media:description: Activists picket against Uganda's anti-homosexuality bill at the Uganda High Commission on April 4, 2023 in Pretoria, South Africa.

item.title: North Korea says it tested a new hypersonic intermediate-range missile that uses solid propellants
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: North Korea said Wednesday it had tested a new hypersonic intermediate-range missile powered with solid propellants, extending a run in weapons demonstrations that’s deepening a nuclear standoff with neighbors and the United States.

media:content.media:text: North Korea says it tested a new hypersonic intermediate-range missile that uses solid propellants
media:content.media:description: Images taken on Tuesday show the first test-fire of North Korean Hwasongpho-16B, a new-type intermediate-range fuelled ballistic missile.

media:content.media:text: North Korea says it tested a new hypersonic intermediate-range missile that uses solid propellants
media:content.media:description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un inspecting the first test-fire, which took place in the suburbs of Pyongyang on Tuesday.

item.title: Russia says concert attack sparked jump in army recruitment as Ukraine lowers conscription age to boost troop numbers
item.dc:creator: Reuters and The Associated Press
item.description: Russia has seen a significant jump in the number of people signing contracts to join the armed forces since last month’s deadly attack on a concert hall near Moscow, the defense ministry said on Wednesday.

media:content.media:text: Russia Military Recruitment Moscow
media:content.media:description: A sign reads "Our profession is defending the Motherland" at a Russian military recruitment point in Moscow.

media:content.media:text: Ukraine on Wednesday, April 3, 2024, lowered the military conscription age from 27 to 25 in an effort to replenish its depleted ranks after more than two years of war following Russia’s full-scale invasion.
media:content.media:description: Conscription has been a sensitive matter in Ukraine and a growing shortage of infantry has helped hand Russia the battlefield initiative.

item.title: J.K. Rowling will not be arrested for comments about transgender women, police say
item.dc:creator: Matt Lavietes
item.description: "Harry Potter" author J.K. Rowling slammed a newly enacted hate-crime law in Scotland in a series of posts on X in which she referred to transgender women as men.

media:content.media:text: J. K. Rowling.
media:content.media:description: J.K. Rowling in Edinburgh on Feb. 24.

item.title: Supporting the team or the SS? German soccer jersey with No. 44 pulled over Nazi symbolism
item.dc:creator: Mithil Aggarwal
item.description: German soccer fans have been banned from customizing a jersey with the number 44 because of a resemblance to the lightning bolts symbol used by Nazi SS units.

media:content.media:text: An official Germany soccer jersey displaying the number 4 ahead of the upcoming UEFA Euro 2024 championship.
media:content.media:description: An official German soccer jersey displaying No. 4 ahead of the UEFA Euro 2024 championship.

media:content.media:text: Waffen-SS
media:content.media:description: A recruitment poster for the Waffen-SS, circa 1940.

item.title: Peru's president replaces 6 ministers as she battles scandal over luxury watches
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Peruvian President Dina Boluarte replaced six ministers after they resigned as her government is rocked by a political crisis fueled by an alleged illicit enrichment scandal involving luxury watches.

media:content.media:text: Dina Boluarte gives a press conference in Lima in 2023.
media:content.media:description: President Dina Boluarte at a press conference in Lima, Peru, last year.

media:content.media:text: Police guard outside President Dina Boluarte's house.
media:content.media:description: Police outside President Dina Boluarte's house in Lima during a raid ordered by the attorney general's office on Saturday.

item.title: Fire at an Istanbul nightclub kills at least 29 people
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: A fire at a nightclub in the Turkish city of Istanbul on Tuesday killed at least 29 people, officials and reports said.

media:content.media:text: Relatives of victims react near the site of a fire in a residential building in Istanbul on April 2, 2024.
media:content.media:description: Relatives of victims react near the site of a fire in a residential building in Istanbul on April 2, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Firefighters work at the scene of a fire in a nightclub in Istanbul Tuesday, April 2, 2024.
media:content.media:description: Firefighters work at the scene of the blaze.

item.title: Benedict backed me up on rights for LGBTQ couples, Pope Francis says
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Pope Francis found an ally in his predecessor Benedict XVI when he spoke in favor of civil partnerships for same-sex couples, the pontiff said in an upcoming new book.

media:content.media:text: Pope Francis and Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI
media:content.media:description: Pope Francis visited Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI in St. Peter's Basilica on Aug. 27, 2022.

item.title: Eight passengers stranded on African island after Norwegian cruise ship left without them
item.dc:creator: Marlene Lenthang and Arnav Jain
item.description: A dream cruise vacation has turned into a nightmare for eight passengers left stranded on the African island of São Tomé and Príncipe after their ship left without them because they were late to return from a private tour.

media:content.media:text: Jill and Jay Campbell.
media:content.media:description: Jill and Jay Campbell.

item.title: American teenager among 3 killed in an avalanche near the Swiss resort of Zermatt
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: An American teenager and two other people were killed in avalanche near the Swiss resort of Zermatt, police said Tuesday.

media:content.media:credit: Police Cantonale Valaisanne via AFP - Getty Images
media:content.media:text: Search operations after an avalanche at Zermatt ski resort, in Valais, Switzerland
media:content.media:description: Search operations after an avalanche at Zermatt ski resort in Valais, Switzerland, on Monday.
